Contemporary military thinking is generally that torture is generally a bad method of extracting information. Information recived under torture is terribly unreliable and generally not worth the effot it takes to collect it because once you hurt somebody badkly enough,they will say anything to make you stop.

 "The prisoner known around the U.S. naval station at Guantánamo Bay as Detainee 063 was a hard man to break. Defiant from the start, he told his captors that he had been in Afghanistan to pursue his love of falconry. But the young Saudi prisoner who wouldn't talk was not just any detainee. He was Mohammed al-Qahtani, a follower of Osama bin Laden's and the man believed by many to be the so-called 20th hijacker. He had tried to enter the U.S. in August 2001, allegedly to take part in the Sept. 11 attacks. But while Mohammed Atta, the eventual leader of the hijackers, was waiting outside in the Orlando,..."

Comment: I guess we're supposed to accept this report as definitive proof that Gitmo is great.They must really think we're major fools. The rehearsed interrogation with Harry Potter is really hard to believe but these guys were reporting it with a straight face. Sounds like the soldier doing the interrogation was having some fun with the guests and they didn't even get the joke.
 
 How about some unscheduled visits to Gitmo to see what's happening. The International Red Cross has made some surprise visits but they are not permitted to release the findings to the public. Why is it so difficult to set up a policy that promotes compliance to regulations?
 Why do we even need to be suspicious?
